text: ——Noon.
The fog thins. Street sounds return beyond the window: hooves on stone, vendors calling, the ringing echo of hammer against iron. The tavern almost feels like a normal day again.
I reset the morning’s cups and straighten the chair that was knocked aside. My knuckles still tingle faintly.
But the more I try to settle back into routine, the more I feel that strange certainty hasn’t faded—like a thin wire pulled tight in my mind, reminding me: she’s still upstairs.
A light sound from the stairs. The third step—I hold my breath without meaning to.
Alicia comes down.
She hasn’t changed out of her armor, only loosened her cloak, like she’s just climbed out of a long dream. But her steps are steady—too steady. As if this place has always been hers.
“Are you… okay?”
“No.”
The bluntness catches me off guard.
“But at least I did one thing right today.”
Her gaze drifts to the bruise on my face, lingering—like she’s inspecting something she absolutely must keep intact.
“You didn’t get hit by the second punch.”
“There it is again—the ‘second punch.’ What are you—”
“Shh.”
She raises a finger, like she’s stopping me from pushing open a door that shouldn’t be opened.
Then she does something even stranger—
She places one candle on the counter. Then a second. Then a third.
They’re new. Still tied with thin twine. Like she prepared them in advance.
“…What are you doing?”
“Inviting you to dinner.”
She says it casually, as if she’s only asking to borrow a flame. But her eyes are tight—tight like someone gripping a rope at the edge of a cliff.
“You’re inviting me?”
“Yes.”
“Candlelight dinner. Tonight.”
As if afraid I’ll refuse, her words begin to spill faster.
“I’ve missed you too many times.”
“Every time I think, ‘Next time I’ll sound more normal.’ ‘Next time I’ll make you smile first.’ ‘Next time I won’t scare you.’”
She falters slightly, the shape of a smile tugging at her mouth but not quite forming.
“But next time is never enough.”
“So this time, I’m not waiting.”
Her fingertip taps the counter lightly, like setting a rule into place.
“Wipe the table clean. Salt on the left.”
A flash of satisfaction crosses her eyes—like she’s anchored reality with a tiny nail.
“…You even remember that.”
“I remember far more.”
She pauses, as if calculating how much truth will make me run.
“I have a task coming up.”
“I might be busy. I might get hurt. I might…”
Her throat moves. The rest of the sentence disappears.
“So tonight, I want to sit here and eat one meal like a normal person.”
She looks at me directly now. No riddles. No deflection.
“Will you come?”

options.text: Option A: Agree to her and prepare dinner 【No Check (DC 0)】
